function_call.name: classify_risks_PESTLE
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Insufficient data on minimum ventilation requirement for public premises","category":"Inadequate urban planning for infectious disease containment","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Influence of inlet and outlet positions on particle deposition and airflow velocity","category":"Inadequate urban planning for infectious disease containment","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Comparison of ventilation supply systems in a hospital environment","category":"Inadequate hospital design ","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Downward ventilation may not always protect people from cross-infection due to mixing ventilation and free convection around the human body.","category":"Inadequate urban planning for infectious disease containment","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Displacement ventilation performs worse when patients are lying sideways, leading to the persistence of exhalation jets over a long distance.","category":"Inadequate hospital design ","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Increasing the throw of the supply jet from the floor diffuser can deteriorate inhaled air quality and promote resuspension of particles including those carrying respiratory pathogens.","category":"Inadequate urban planning for infectious disease containment","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Dependence of air containment","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Increasing human impacts from building practices","category":"Poor urban planning","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Tight time and budgetary constraints in planning","confidence":"Low"},{"name":"Regenerative development and design may be unfeasible in complex urban situations due to social and political pressures, limiting the implementation of
